info.game_comments:
2016 Teachers Tournament semifinal game 1.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: The compass seen here was used on this pair's 1804-1806 expedition

(3, 1).clue: Oman, they got troubles & the main one is the fall in the price of this since 2014

(4, 1).clue: The hyoid bone in your throat helps anchor this body part on whose tip some answers may be found

(5, 1).clue: A Broadway nightclub, Birdland, was named for him; he performed on opening night in late 1949

(6, 1).clue: To work dough by pressing & stretching

(1, 2).clue: The evening gown worn by this first lady to her first state dinner was created by Oleg Cassini, one of her favorite designers

(3, 2).clue: This former rival for the nomination was the first sitting governor to endorse Donald Trump

(4, 2).clue: A dislocated shoulder occurs when the head of this bone comes out of the socket--hey, that's not funny at all

(5, 2).clue: This trumpeter helped shape jazz as we know it today

(6, 2).clue: You have this special skill at something, like playing "My Sharona"

(1, 3).clue: Here's the mask worn by Clayton Moore as this character on 1950s TV

(3, 3).clue: A letter of Feb. 23, 2016 let Obama know, "This committee will not hold hearings" until Jan. 20, 2017

(4, 3).clue: The name of this long, strong bone is from the Latin for "thigh"

(5, 3).clue: This man, son of Ellis & brother of Branford, was given his first trumpet by Al Hirt

(6, 3).clue: It's the wacky baseball pitch that fits the category

(1, 4).clue: Weighing in at 45.52 karats, it was donated to the Smithsonian by Harry Winston in 1958

(3, 4).clue: The April 2016 leak of records of hidden overseas accounts was called this Central American country's "Papers"

(4, 4).clue: These S-curved bones articulate medially with the breastbone & with the tops of the shoulders

(5, 4).clue: Eulogizing this longtime bandmate, Bruce Springsteen said, "He loved the saxophone, loved our fans"

(6, 4).clue: Competition format in which losers are eliminated after each round

(1, 5).clue: In the 1870s, this firearms company began turning out a new product--typewriters like the one seen here

(3, 5).clue: In 2015 Brazil's first infection from this virus was diagnosed; in 2016 it became an international concern

(5, 5).clue: Pardon me boy, but it was this trombonist who gave us "Chattanooga Choo Choo" in 1941

(6, 5).clue: They're short, loose-fitting trousers gathered in at the knees

(1, 1).clue: This European leader is seen here as she looked early in her political career

(2, 1).clue: A popular game inspired the new movie about this title group, starring Jason Sudeikis as Red"Beak! Wing! Tail!Ribs! Giblets!Ugh.  Pluck my life."

(3, 1).clue: In a 1939 film this character says, "I haven't any courage at all.  I even scare myself!"

(4, 1).clue: This father of Icarus was considered the first aviator

(5, 1).clue: This capital of Indonesia is home to about 10 million people

(6, 1).clue: Celebrated in March, it marks the anniversary of the death of a 5th century bishop of Armagh

(1, 2).clue: Family name of the current president of South Korea, whose father was assassinated when he was president

(2, 2).clue: This Christopher Nolan film told the origin story of the Caped Crusader

(3, 2).clue: This noble lion is the son of the Emperor-Over-the-Sea in the Narnia stories

(4, 2).clue: In Norse myth these maidens chose the men who were to die in battle & then brought them to Valhalla

(5, 2).clue: The Shung Ye Museum of Formosan Aborigines is a popular attraction in this city

(6, 2).clue: Lexicon & wordfinder are synonyms for this book first published in 1852

(1, 3).clue: Nicknamed "Iron Erna", PM Erna Solberg is also the head of this political party in Norway

(2, 3).clue: This Steve Carell film explores the housing bubble collapse of 2007-08

(3, 3).clue: In the 1930s mayor Fiorello La Guardia named the 2 marble lions in front of this building Patience & Fortitude

(4, 3).clue: Alphabetically this Babylonian goddess of love & fertility comes between Iris & Isis

(5, 3).clue: This capital of Bangladesh is in the heart of the world's largest jute-growing region

(6, 3).clue: Proverbial expression for a situation where you are only offered one selection

(1, 4).clue: She was just 35 when she became prime minister of Pakistan

(2, 4).clue: "I love the smell of napalm in the morning", says Robert Duvall in this film set during the Vietnam War

(3, 4).clue: This legendary 1st century slave is said to have removed a thorn from a lion's paw & was later saved by the same lion

(4, 4).clue: After Pandora opened her box & released all the evils, only this remained

(5, 4).clue: Dating from before the year 1, Tashkent, the capital of this "stan", is one of the oldest cities of Central Asia

(1, 5).clue: In 2011 she succeeded her mentor Lula as president of Brazil

(2, 5).clue: This sci-fi film was based on the novel "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?"

(3, 5).clue: In 1956 George Adamson killed a lioness but rescued this cub about whom his wife Joy later wrote

(4, 5).clue: Greek gods swore their most sacred oaths in the name of this daughter of Oceanus & her river

(5, 5).clue: Tango & Cheri are important Buddhist monasteries near Thimphu in this Himalayan nation

(0, 0).clue: The original law called this was passed in 1944; today, there's a "Post-9/11" version that also pays for 36 months of university education
